Line 41: Line 41:
With the third season, writers such as [[Ronald D. Moore]] from the now completed [[Star Trek: The Next Generation]] began to write regularly for DS9.<ref name="IGN p7" /> [[Robert Hewitt Wolfe]] joined [[Ira Steven Behr]] in writing the episodes concerning the Dominion, beginning with [[The Search (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|âThe Searchâ]]. Ira Behr became full Executive Producer mid-way through the season, with the departure of Michael Piller.
With the third season, writers such as [[Ronald D. Moore]] from the now completed [[Star Trek: The Next Generation]] began to write regularly for DS9.<ref name="IGN p7" /> [[Robert Hewitt Wolfe]] joined [[Ira Steven Behr]] in writing the episodes concerning the Dominion, beginning with [[The Search (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|âThe Searchâ]]. Ira Behr became full Executive Producer mid-way through the season, with the departure of Michael Piller.
â
[[File:USS Defiant leaving DS9 damaged.jpg|thumb|right|USS Defiant barely misses one of [[Deep Space 9]]'s lower docking pylons in ''[[For the Uniform]]''.]]
 
At the start of DS9âs third season, in the episode [[The Search (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|âThe Searchâ]], Commander Sisko returns from Starfleet Headquarters on Earth with the [[USS Defiant (NX-74205)|USS ''Defiant'']], a prototype starship.<ref name="The Search: Part 1" /> Executive Producer Rick Berman had to be convinced that this would not take focus away from the starship fronting the new series [[Star Trek: Voyager]] which he was now developing. The decision was made on the basis of the need for a vehicle to provide for stories away from the [[Deep Space Nine (space station)|Deep Space Nine]] station, and a requirement for a vessel able to oppose potential threats from the new [[Jem'Hadar]] enemy that had been devised, which had already been portrayed destroying powerful Starfleet starships. Audience research had also suggested that young male viewers were hoping for more action-oriented shows with greater jeopardy.<ref name="Deep Space Nine Companionp158">{{Cite book| last1 = Erdmann| first1 = Terry| last2 = Block| first2 = Paula| title = The Star Trek: Deep Space Nine Companion| publisher = Pocket Books, Simon & Schuster Inc.| location = New York City | date = 2000| page = 158 | doi = | isbn = 1-0671-5010-62 }}</ref>
At the start of DS9âs third season, in the episode [[The Search (Star Trek: Deep Space Nine)|âThe Searchâ]], Commander Sisko returns from Starfleet Headquarters on Earth with the [[USS Defiant (NX-74205)|USS ''Defiant'']], a prototype starship.<ref name="The Search: Part 1" /> Executive Producer Rick Berman had to be convinced that this would not take focus away from the starship fronting the new series [[Star Trek: Voyager]] which he was now developing. The decision was made on the basis of the need for a vehicle to provide for stories away from the [[Deep Space Nine (space station)|Deep Space Nine]] station, and a requirement for a vessel able to oppose potential threats from the new [[Jem'Hadar]] enemy that had been devised, which had already been portrayed destroying powerful Starfleet starships. Audience research had also suggested that young male viewers were hoping for more action-oriented shows with greater jeopardy.<ref name="Deep Space Nine Companionp158">{{Cite book| last1 = Erdmann| first1 = Terry| last2 = Block| first2 = Paula| title = The Star Trek: Deep Space Nine Companion| publisher = Pocket Books, Simon & Schuster Inc.| location = New York City | date = 2000| page = 158 | doi = | isbn = 1-0671-5010-62 }}</ref>
